awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms Governing DNA Replication Timing and Copy Number Control During Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Mechanisms governing DNA replication timing and copy number control during development 

The genomes of eukaryotic organisms contain millions to billions of base pairs of DNA that must be accurately copied every time a cell divides. Failure to accurately copy DNA can cause mutations that alter cell function or even lead to cell death. Given the complexity of copying DNA, this process can take many hours to complete. DNA is not copied randomly, but rather particular DNA sequences are replicated at specific times during the period of genome replication. This project will utilize interdisciplinary approaches to understand how key factors control when a specific DNA sequence is replicated. The project will also provide educational and research opportunities to benefit both teachers and students. First, we will provide direct and hands-on research opportunities for Nashville area high school teachers to aid in the development of an experimental-based curriculum. Second, we will develop new approaches in the classroom to expose undergraduate and graduate students to the power of using interdisciplinary approaches to solve unanswered questions in biology. Lastly, we will provide hands-on research opportunities to undergraduate students at Vanderbilt.

Rif1 has been shown to control the replication timing program from yeast to humans, but precisely how Rif1 performs this function remains unknown. This project aims to identify how Rif1 activity is regulated during development and thus help determine the replication timing program. Using Drosophila melanogaster as a model system, we have found that Rif1 associates with the replication machinery in a developmentally programmed manner. We will combine the powerful developmental systems of Drosophila, with biochemical and proteomic approaches to determine how Rif1 associates with the replication machinery. We will then use a combination of genetics and genomics strategies to determine how Rif1 influences replication timing in different developmental contexts. Finally, we will apply chromosome conformation capture techniques to interrogate the molecular mechanisms that Rif1 utilizes to regulate the replication timing program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A conserved feature of genome duplication in all organisms is the replication timing program, which is the relative time in S phase when a particular genomic sequence is replicated. While the process of replication timing is conserved from yeast to humans, the underlying molecular mechanisms that control replication timing are poorly defined. One factor known to control the replication timing program from yeast to humans is Rif1. Rif1, however, has many functions and it is unclear how these multiple activities of Rif1 are coordinated to control replication timing and how Rif1 activity is regulated during development. Our goal is to provide a better understanding of how Rif1 controls replication timing and how Rif1 activity is controlled during development.

Intellectual Merit: This award has resulted in four publications. Furthermore, we have generated rich mass spectrometry and genome-wide sequencing data sets that will continue to fuel future research efforts.

We defined Rif1’s contribution to genome-wide replication timing across multiple Drosophila tissues. We found that Rif1 influences tissue-specific patterns of replication timing and this happens independently of transcription. Furthermore, we discovered that Rif1 function is completely dependent on its ability to bind protein phosphatase 1.

 By applying a computational approach to measure replication timing in Drosophila endocycling cells, we were able to generate the first high-resolution replication timing data sets in large polyploid cells. We were then able to assess the contributions Rif1 and SUUR have on replication timing and programmed changes in gene copy number known as underreplication. Our work revealed that Rif1 regulates both copy number and replication timing. Furthermore, we found that SUUR-dependent changes in copy number depend on Rif1 to promote late replication. 

While identifying proteins that work with Rif1 to control replication timing, we identified an unexpected link between replication initiation and a subcomplex of the nuclear pore. We found that specific nuclear pore proteins function to promote replication initiation.   

Broader Impacts: Two graduate students, four undergraduates and two technicians were associated with this award. This award also provided training for two high school teachers.

Modified by: Jared Nordman
